awd_titl_txt: Harnessing Machine Learning to Study the Life Cycle of Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars like our Sun are born in large clouds of gas that usually produce thousands of stars at once. As the stars form, they add energy back into their environment ('feedback') and influence the birth gas cloud. This feedback appears as fast-moving gas, which sometimes looks like large bubbles. The data are complex, so identifying feedback is difficult. Typically, astronomers have found the feedback "by eye", which is subjective and time-consuming. A new field of computer science, machine learning, provides an alternative approach to find feedback. In machine learning, computer algorithms are trained to identify features in the same way the human brain recognizes objects - like cats, dogs and cars.  The investigator's group will use state-of-the-art models of forming stars to train machine learning algorithms to find feedback. They will apply the algorithms to telescope observations and compare with the feedback sources previously found by humans. 

The investigator will share the models with the public through the Milky Way project, which is an online astronomy program that trains people to identify feedback in telescope images of gas clouds. The program will also train students in research techniques, including undergraduates from underrepresented groups. 

The proposal addresses a fundamental star formation question:  How much mass and energy is associated with stellar feedback in the interstellar medium?  To answer this question, the PI and collaborators will use magnetohydrodynamic simulations of forming stars, for which full feedback information is known, to train machine learning algorithms to identify and quantify feedback. Dust and molecular line 'synthetic observations' will be produced and used together with observational data as a training set.  The investigators will compare the machine learning identifications to prior visually identified feedback catalogs, including those from the citizen-science Milky Way Project, create an updated census, and publicly release the algorithm and data to the community. The broader impact objectives are to increase public participation in the Milky Way Project, develop a WorldWide Telescope tour on feedback, and train students, including undergraduates in the Texas Astronomy Undergraduate Research experience for Under-Represented Students (TAURUS) summer program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Stars forming close together influence each other and their birth environment by injecting energy in the form of radiation, winds and jets ("stellar feedback"). Identifying this feedback "by eye" is challenging, time consuming and subjective. Machine learning, a field of computer science in which algorithms can learn and evolve without explicit programming, provides a powerful alternative to visual identification. 

This project combined numerical models of forming stars, machine learning methods and telescope observations to find and study stellar feedback. The project team developed three different machine learning methods and then used numerical models to train them to identify feedback in infrared and radio observations. The Convolutional Approach to Structure Identification in 3 Dimensions (CASI-3D) was the first such method to be created and applied to detect 3D structures in telescope observations.

The project team compared with previously published surveys, which identified the location of stellar feedback by eye, and showed that visual identification can both miss feedback features and over-estimate their impact, leading to significant errors.   The team carried out a complete survey of feedback in the four nearest star-forming regions: Taurus, Perseus, Orion and Ophiuchus.  In all cases, feedback from young stars is adding significant energy to the region and shaping the properties of the star-forming gas. In a separate analysis, CASI-3D was trained to predict the direction of the stellar feedback. The project team compared the directions of the stellar feedback with observations of the gas magnetic field direction and showed that they tend to be aligned with one another.

The funded project has provided frameworks for automatically identifying features in observational data and an approach to estimate the distribution of young stars and the impact of their feedback. All machine learning methods developed during the project were publicly released. As a general method, CASI-3D is suitable for science applications beyond astronomy. For example, the project team partnered with geosystems researchers to predict properties of groundwater flow.

Broader Impacts: The project team partnered with the Milky Way Project citizen science team to compare the properties of feedback bubbles identified by eye and by machine learning. Thousands of members of the public participated in classifying bubbles in the observational data. The project provided research training for two PhD students and five undergraduates, three of whom participated in the Texas Astronomy Undergraduate Research experience for Under-represented Students (TAURUS) summer program. More than 30 scientific and public talks were given on the project methods and results.


Last Modified: 12/17/2022
Modified by: Stella Offner

Images (1 of )
  • Blue shows an observation of gas in in the Taurus star-forming region. Red marks a bubble created by a young star, which was identified by machine learning.
    https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2020ApJ...890...64X/abstract
    Public Domain
    Stella Offner
    Stellar bubble in Taurus
  • Red and blue contours show outflows from young stars in the Orion region identified by machine learning. Yellow bars indicate the outflow direction. The background curves indicate the direction of the magnetic field.
    https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2022arXiv221103781X/abstract
    Public Domain
    Stella Offner
    Stellar feedback in Orion
